questions.text: All of the following coagulation factors increase in pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Factor XI

 

Explanation:

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state to facilitate hemostasis during labor and placental separation. In pregnancy, most coagulation factors are increased, except for Factor XI and Factor XIII.

 

Hematological changes in pregnancy:

 

Factors Increasing

Factors Decreasing
  • Fibrinogen
  • Coagulation factors 7, 8, 9, 10
  • Insulin
  • LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein)
  • Apolipoproteins
  • Transferrin and TIBC (Total Iron Binding Capacity)
  • CRP (C-Reactive Protein)
  • Placental phosphatase
  • Total alkaline phosphatase
  • Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)
  • Iron and Ferritin
  • Neutrophils
  • Hemoglobin concentration
  • Total plasma protein
  • Globulin
  • Albumin
  • Platelets
  • Blood urea nitrogen (BUN)
  • Urea/Creatinine/Uric acid
  • Factor 11, 13
  • Sodium (Na)
  • Potassium (K)
  • Calcium (Ca)
  • Magnesium (Mg)
  • Iron stores and Ferritin

questions.text: In a woman with a regular 28-day menstrual cycle, which of the following best describes the typical hormonal profile during days 21 to 25 of the cycle?

choices.text: Low estrogen, high progesterone, low LH and FSH
Low estrogen, low progesterone, low LH and FSH
Low estrogen, high progesterone, high LH and FSH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Low estrogen, high progesterone, low LH and FSH

  • Days 21–25 fall in the mid-to-late luteal phase when the corpus luteum secretes high progesterone (to maintain the endometrium). Progesterone (with moderate estrogen) exerts negative feedback on the pituitary, keeping LH and FSH low.
  • In the mid-luteal (post-ovulation) phase, there is progesterone peak due to increased production from corpus luteum to maintain a secretory endometrium.
  • Estrogen: Moderate to low relative to the pre-ovulatory peak.
  • LH/FSH: Suppressed by progesterone/estrogen negative feedback.
  • If no fertilization, corpus luteum involutes → progesterone/estrogen fall → menstruation begins.

Low estrogen, low progesterone, low LH and FSH (Option B): This profile describes the early follicular phase (menstrual bleeding) when both ovarian steroids are low; it is not the luteal phase.

Low estrogen, high progesterone, high LH and FSH (Option C): LH/FSH are not high in the luteal phase; the gonadotropin surge (high LH/FSH) occurs at ovulation (~day 14), not days 21–25.

High estrogen, high progesterone (Option D): Simultaneous high levels of both are typical with early pregnancy (corpus luteum/placental support), not the normal mid-luteal state of a non-pregnant cycle.
 

Phase

Days

Estrogen

Progesterone

LH

FSH

Early Follicular

1–5

Low

Low

Low-normal ↑

Low-normal ↑

Late Follicular

6–13

High

Low

Low

Low

Ovulation

~14

Peak

Low

High surge

High surge

Early Luteal

15–20

Moderate

High

Low

Low

Late Luteal

Low-moderate

High

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has developed breast and pubic hair. The mother wants to know which sign of puberty will typically occur next?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Peak height

Explanation:

Pubertal development in girls generally follows Tanner’s sequence:

  1. Thelarche – breast development (usually the first sign, ~8–11 years)
  2. Pubarche – pubic hair development
  3. Peak height velocity – occurs about 1 year after thelarche and before menarche
  4. Menarche – typically 2–2.5 years after thelarche, after peak growth has occurred
  5. Axillary hair – develops later in the sequence
  6. Vaginal discharge – may occur just before menarche

Since this girl already has breast and pubic hair, the next expected milestone is peak height velocity.

Incorrect Options:

Vaginal discharge (Option A): May occur just before menarche, but not typically right after thelarche/puberty onset.

Menarche (Option C): Usually occurs about 2 years after breast development starts; not the immediate next milestone.

Axillary hair development (Option D):Comes later, usually after pubic hair is well established and often after menarche.

questions.text: A 12-year-old female presents with Tanner stage II breast development and white, odorless vaginal discharge. This discharge is most likely due to the action of which hormone?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Estrogen

Explanation:

  • In early puberty, rising estrogen levels stimulate the vaginal epithelium to proliferate and produce glycogen.
  • This glycogen supports lactobacilli growth, leading to acidic pH and physiological leukorrhea — a normal, odorless, white discharge before menarche.
  • Tanner stage II = breast budding; estrogen effects become evident on genital mucosa.
  • Discharge is not associated with infection, pain, or foul smell — reassurance is key.

Incorrect Options:

GnRH (Option A): Hypothalamic hormone that triggers pituitary LH/FSH release; indirectly influences puberty but does not directly cause vaginal epithelial changes or leukorrhea.

Inhibin B (Option C): Secreted by ovarian granulosa cells; inhibits FSH; no role in vaginal discharge production.

B-Lynch suture (Option D): Surgical technique for postpartum hemorrhage control; unrelated to puberty or vaginal secretions.

questions.text: The following chart shows the hormonal variations in the menstrual cycle. Identify the true statement:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) White Line represents FSH hormone

Explanation:

  • The White Line in the chart represents FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone).
  • FSH is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland and It stimulates the growth and maturation of ovarian follicles in the first half of the menstrual cycle. FSH levels typically rise during the follicular phase and then decline as ovulation approaches.

Hormones Involved in the Menstrual Cycle

Hormone

Origin

Triggering Factors

Peak Timing

Role

Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

(Option C)

Anterior pituitary

Surge in GnRH from hypothalamus, feedback from estrogen/progesterone

Just before ovulation

Triggers ovulation, supports corpus luteum formation, stimulates progesterone secretion.

Estrogen (Estradiol)

(Option A)

Granulosa cells of ovarian follicles

Stimulated by FSH and LH, increases with follicular growth

Just before ovulation (mid-cycle)

Stimulates follicle growth, thickens endometrial lining, regulates FSH and LH through feedback mechanisms.

Progesterone

(Option D)

Corpus luteum (post-ovulation)

LH surge, transformation of follicle to corpus luteum

Post-ovulation, during luteal phase

Maintains uterine lining for implantation, inhibits ovulation, supports pregnancy if fertilization occurs.

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Anterior pituitary

GnRH from hypothalamus, modulated by estrogen feedback

Just before ovulation, during follicular phase

Stimulates follicle growth and estrogen production to support follicular development and progression of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, married for the past 5 years, presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse. Physical examination is unremarkable. Semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly shown in the image below falls under which category of the American Fertility Society classification of Müllerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Class II

Explanation:

  • As described in the image given above, the Hysterosalpingography (HSG) demonstrates a characteristic appearance of a unicornuate uterus, where one Müllerian duct has failed to develop completely.
  • This anomaly is classified as Class II under the American Society for Reproductive Medicine (ASRM) classification of Müllerian anomalies.
     

Müllerian Duct Anomaly

Description

Clinical Features

Diagnosis

Management

Class I

 

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) Syndrome

 

(Option D)
  • Complete or partial absence of the uterus and upper two-thirds of the vagina.
  • Ovaries are normal.
  • Primary amenorrhea.
  • Absence of menstruation.
  • Normal secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Pelvic ultrasound.
  • MRI.
  • Karyotyping.
  • Vaginal reconstruction.
  • Assisted reproduction for fertility (gestational surrogacy or oocyte donation).

Class II

Unicornuate Uterus
  • Uterus is smaller and only one side develops.
  • Can have a rudimentary horn.
  • Dysmenorrhea.
  • Infertility.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Ectopic pregnancy.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG).
  • MRI.
  • Surgical removal of rudimentary horn.
  • Fertility management.
  • Cesarean delivery in case of pregnancy.

Class III

Bicornuate Uterus

 

(Option B)
  • Uterus has two horns.
  • Often with a deep indentation in the upper part.
  • Single cervix.
  • Menstrual irregularities.
  • Recurrent pregnancy loss.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction (metroplasty) in some cases.
  • Supportive care for pregnancy management.

Class IV

Septate Uterus

 

(Option A)
  • Normally shaped uterus but with a fibrous or muscular septum dividing the cavity.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Infertility.
  • Preterm labor.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Sonohysterogram.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical resection of the septum (hysteroscopic septoplasty).
  • Fertility treatments if needed.

Class V

Arcuate Uterus
  • Mild indentation of the uterine fundus with a normal external uterine contour.
  • Often asymptomatic.
  • May have recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm birth.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Typically no treatment required.
  • Management of complications like miscarriage may be necessary.

Class VI

Didelphys Uterus

 
  • Complete non-fusion of the Müllerian ducts.
  • Two separate uterine cavities and cervices.
  • Vaginal septum.
  • Recurrent miscarriage.
  • Preterm labor.
  • Infertility.
  • HSG.
  • MRI.
  • Laparoscopy.
  • Surgical correction if needed.
  • Assisted reproductive techniques (ART) for infertility.

questions.text: What does the ferning pattern of drying cervical mucus indicate in terms of its mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Estrogen

Explanation:

  • The ferning pattern of drying cervical mucus is caused by the influence of estrogen.
  • During the follicular phase of the menstrual cycle, rising estrogen levels cause cervical mucus to become thin, clear, and elastic, facilitating sperm movement.
  • When dried, this mucus exhibits a characteristic fern-like pattern under the microscope due to the crystallization of sodium chloride in the mucus, which is influenced by estrogen.

Organ/System

Estrogen

Progesterone

Uterus

Proliferates endometrium.

Has a secretory effect on the endometrium.

Upregulates progesterone receptors on endometrium.

Downregulates estrogen receptors.

Leads to the growth of the non-pregnant uterus.

Promotes the growth of the pregnant uterus (in estrogen-primed endometrium).

Cervix

Cervical mucus is thin, watery, copious, and elastic.

Cervical mucus is thick, scanty, viscous, and non-elastic.

Permeable to sperm.

Impermeable to sperm.

Fern-like appearance on microscopy (day 8 of cycle).

Ferning disappears by day 18 of the cycle.

Vagina

Superficial cells (eosinophilic, pyknotic nucleus) predominate in the first half of the cycle.

Intermediate cells (basophilic, small nucleus) predominate in the second half of the cycle.

Breast

Promotes ductal growth.

Promotes glandular growth.

Salt & Water Regulation

Causes retention of salt and water.

Promotes excretion of salt and water.

Fallopian Tube

Increases motility and decreases secretions.

Decreases motility and increases secretions.

Lipid Profile

Increases HDL, LDL, and triglycerides.

Increases HDL but lowers LDL and triglycerides (3rd/4th gen progesterones are cardioprotective).

Incorrect Options:

Progesterone (Option B) leads to thick and sticky cervical mucus, which does not show a ferning pattern. It is predominant in the luteal phase of the cycle.

Prolactin (Option C) is mainly associated with lactation and does not affect the properties of cervical mucus.

17-ketosteroids (Option D) are adrenal hormone metabolites and do not play a role in the changes seen in cervical mucus.

questions.text: What is the appropriate evaluation for a 30-year-old woman who visits an infertility clinic and has a consistent 28 day menstrual cycle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Serum progesterone day 21

Explanation:

  • In a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, the evaluation for ovulation can be done by measuring serum progesterone levels on day 21 of the menstrual cycle. Day 21 corresponds to the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle when progesterone levels should be elevated if ovulation has occurred.

 

Day 14 corresponds to the expected time of ovulation in a woman with a regular 28-day cycle. Serum progesterone levels on day 14 (Option A) may not accurately reflect whether ovulation has occurred.

Serum luteinizing hormone (LH) levels surge just before ovulation. However, in a woman with a regular 28-day cycle, day 14 (Option C) may not correspond to the actual day of ovulation.

LH levels return to baseline after ovulation, so measuring serum LH on day 21 (Option D) may not provide accurate information about ovulation.

questions.text: After 18 hours of which peak in the provided image is associated with the occurrence of ovulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:

Ovulation occurs during Luteinizing hormone peak, which stimulates egg release (ovulation), which usually occurs 16 to 32 hours after the surge begins.

  • The process of ovulation begins when the hypothalamus releases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH).
  • GnRH causes the pituitary gland to secrete follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH).
  • The ovulatory phase begins with a surge in luteinizing hormone and follicle-stimulating hormone levels.

Hormonal Changes During Menstrual Cycle

Menstrual Phase

Follicular Phase

Ovulation

Luteal Phase

Follicle-Stimulating Hormone (FSH)

Increased levels

    

Luteinizing Hormone (LH)

  

Surge in LH levels

  

Estrogen

Low levels

Increased levels

High levels

Progesterone

    

Increased levels

questions.text: Which hormone is secreted by the placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) hCG

 

Explanation:

hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin) is a glycoprotein hormone secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast of the placenta.

It can be detected in the maternal blood and urine as early as 8–9 days post-fertilization using techniques like radioimmunoassay. During early pregnancy, hCG levels double every 1.4–2 days.

 

Functions of hCG:

 

  • Rescue of the Corpus Luteum: The primary role of hCG is to stimulate the secretion of progesterone by the corpus luteum during the first 6 weeks of pregnancy, maintaining the uterine environment.
  • Leydig Cell Stimulation: It stimulates Leydig cells in the male fetus to produce testosterone, which is crucial for male sexual differentiation.
  • Steroidogenesis: hCG supports steroid hormone production by the adrenal glands and placenta.
  • Thyrotropic Activity: It stimulates the maternal thyroid gland due to its structural similarity to TSH, leading to mild thyroid activation during pregnancy.
  • Relaxin Secretion: hCG promotes the secretion of relaxin from the corpus luteum, which helps in softening the cervix and ligaments in late pregnancy.

 

Clinical Implications of hCG Levels:

  • High hCG levels: Associated with multiple pregnancies, hydatidiform mole, choriocarcinoma, and Down syndrome (trisomy 21).
  • Low hCG levels: Seen in ectopic pregnancies and impending miscarriages.

 

LH (Luteinizing Hormone) (Option A) is secreted by the anterior pituitary gland, not the placenta. It plays a crucial role in ovulation and maintaining the corpus luteum.

 

FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) (Option C) is also secreted by the anterior pituitary and is involved in stimulating ovarian follicle development in females and spermatogenesis in males, but it is not produced by the placenta.

 

GnRH (Gonadotropin-Releasing Hormone) (Option D) is secreted by the hypothalamus and regulates the secretion of LH and FSH; however, it is unrelated to placental function.

questions.text: All of the following statements about anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) are true, except:

choices.text: It is best tested in the fasting state on day 3 of the menstrual cycle
It is a lipopeptide secreted from granulosa cells of early antral follicles
It correlates with the pregnancy rate of IVF cycles
It decreases the sensitivity of pre-antral follicles to FSH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It is a lipopeptide secreted from granulosa cells of early antral follicles

 

Explanation:

  • AMH is not a lipopeptide but rather a glycopeptide. It is secreted by the granulosa cells of the pre-antral and early antral follicles of the ovaries.
  • In males, AMH inhibits the development of the Mullerian ducts, playing a key role in the sexual differentiation of males.
  • In females, it helps regulate follicular development and oocyte maturation.


Role in Female Reproduction:

  • Follicular Development: AMH actually helps prevent the premature recruitment of follicles by inhibiting the sensitivity of the pre-antral and small antral follicles to FSH. This means that higher AMH levels are associated with better preservation of the ovarian reserve, as it delays the onset of follicular development. (Option D ruled out)

 

  • Ovarian Reserve Indicator: AMH levels correlate with the number of antral follicles and are considered a strong marker for ovarian reserve.

 

AMH Levels and Fertility:

  • High AMH Levels: Elevated AMH levels (>10 ng/mL) are often associated with conditions like Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) and may indicate a higher number of available follicles.
  • Low AMH Levels: Reduced AMH levels (<1 ng/mL) suggest diminished ovarian reserve, which may impact fertility potential.
     

AMH Testing:

  • Purpose: AMH testing is utilized to assess ovarian reserve, predict ovarian response in assisted reproductive technologies like IVF, and evaluate conditions such as PCOS. (Option C ruled out)
  • Timing: AMH levels remain relatively stable throughout the menstrual cycle, allowing for testing at any time. However, measuring AMH on Days 1-3 of the menstrual cycle can provide a more accurate assessment of ovarian reserve. (Option A ruled out)

 

Clinical Implications:

Fertility Assessment: AMH levels assist in evaluating a woman's fertility potential, guiding decisions regarding fertility preservation and treatment options.
IVF Prognosis: In IVF cycles, higher AMH levels are associated with a better ovarian response, leading to higher egg retrieval numbers and potentially increased success rates.

questions.text: What is the hormonal check for pregnancy at home?
questions.solution:
The beta subunit of human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG) is the earliest detectable hormone in pregnancy and is used in home pregnancy tests.

hCG is secreted by the syncytiotrophoblast after implantation, which occurs 5-6 days post-ovulation, and can be detected in urine by 10 days post-ovulation. Levels peak around 8-10 weeks of gestation and then plateau. hCG maintains the corpus luteum, ensuring continued progesterone production until the placenta takes over.

 

Estrogen (Option B) is essential for pregnancy maintenance but is not used for pregnancy detection. The placenta lacks 17-hydroxylase and depends on fetal adrenal precursors (DHEA-S) to synthesize estrogen. It plays a role in uterine growth, blood flow regulation, and fetal development, but cannot confirm pregnancy at home.

 

Progesterone (Option C) is crucial for pregnancy maintenance and is produced by the corpus luteum until 10 weeks, after which the placenta takes over. It helps maintain the endometrium, suppresses the maternal immune response to fetal antigens, and prevents preterm labor. However, progesterone levels alone are not a reliable pregnancy test.


Human Placental Lactogen (hPL) (Option D) is secreted by the placenta and plays a role in maternal metabolism, enhancing insulin resistance to ensure glucose availability for the fetus. It also stimulates lipolysis and protein metabolism. While important in pregnancy, hPL is not used for pregnancy detection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a hyper-estrogenic condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Low BMI

Explanation:

  • Low BMI is not a hyper-estrogenic condition.

Causes of Hyperestrogenism:

  • Ovarian Tumors: Granulosa cell tumors and thecomas. (Option B)
  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT): Long-term or high-dose estrogen therapy can lead to hyperestrogenism.
  • Obesity: Increased fat tissue can lead to higher estrogen levels, as adipose tissue converts androgens into estrogens.
  • Adrenal Tumors or Hyperadrenocorticism: Excess production of adrenal hormones, including estrogen, due to conditions like Cushing's syndrome.
  • Medications: Tamoxifen or estrogen-containing contraceptives (Option D)
  • Endometriosis: Estrogen stimulates the growth of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, leading to hyperestrogenism. (Option C)
  • Liver Disease: Reduce the metabolism of estrogen, leading to its accumulation.
  • Early Puberty or Precocious Puberty: Lead to elevated estrogen production in younger girls due to premature ovarian or adrenal activity.
  • Excessive Alcohol Consumption: Chronic alcohol intake can affect liver function and estrogen metabolism, leading to hyperestrogenism.

questions.text: Where is the SRY region located in the body?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Short arm of Y chromosome

Explanation:

The SRY gene/region is the sex-determining gene/ region present on the short arm of the Y chromosome.

SRY gene

  • Present in the distal region of the short arm of the Y chromosome.
  • Significant in determining the male sex and expresses at the 5th to 6th week of development.
  • When this gene is not expressed, ovarian development takes place in XX karyotype.
  • Mutation of the SRY gene leads to Swyer syndrome.
    • Patients with Swyer syndrome have a karyotype of 46XY, but the Mullerian system develops.
    • These people are phenotypically female with female external and internal genitalia.
    • Gonads are usually streak ovaries with only gonadal stroma, but the vagina, uterus, and fallopian tubes are all formed.

questions.text: What is the underlying reason for the lack of fructose in seminal fluid?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Both of the above

Explanation:

Fructose, a significant energy source for the sperm, is produced by the seminal vesicles and ejaculated in the semen. Hence, any obstruction of the ejaculatory duct or the absence of seminal vesicles can lead to a decreased concentration of fructose in the semen.

The absence of fructose can be seen in:

  • Congenital absence of seminal vesicle
  • Obstruction of ejaculatory duct or vas deferens or seminal vesicle
  • Inflammation of the ejaculatory duct, vas deferens, or seminal vesicle leading to obstruction
  • Congenital absence of the vas deferens

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in 3rd trimester presents to the emergency department after experiencing a fainting episode while lying down. She reports feeling better once she sits up. What is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IVC compression

Explanation:

  • IVC compression causes supine hypotension syndrome
  • During late pregnancy, the gravid uterus produces a compression effect on the inferior vena cava when the patient is in supine position
  • This results in opening up of the collateral circulation by means of paravertebral and azygos veins
  • In some cases (10%), when the collateral circulation fails to open up, the venous return of the heart may be seriously curtailed

Clinical Features:

  • Results in production of hypotension, tachycardia and syncope
  • The normal BP is quickly restored by turning the patient to lateral position (left → right)

Incorrect Options:

SVC compression (Option B): Compression of the superior vena cava can cause symptoms like facial swelling and jugular venous distension, but it is not typically associated with fainting episodes when lying down.

Hypotension (Option C):

  • Hypotension can occur due to IVC compression but it is not the underlying cause of positional syncope seen in the patient.

Motion sickness (Option D):

  • Motion sickness is usually accompanied by nausea and vomiting. It is triggered by motion but not associated with positional changes.

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence with respect to the stages of changes that the breast undergoes in a female?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Mamogenesis→lactogenesis→galactokinesis→galactopoiesis

Explanation:

Sequential Stages of Breast Changes:

  • Mamogenesis:
    • Growth of both ductal and lobuloalveolar system
    • An intact nerve supply is not essential for the growth of mammary glands during pregnancy
  • Lactogenesis:
    • The alveolar cells are the principal sites for the production of milk
    • Milk secretion actually starts on 3rd or 4th postpartum day
  • Galactokinesis:
    • Oxytocin is the major galactokinetic hormone
    • Discharge of milk from the mammary glands depends on suckling and contractile mechanism
  • Galactopoiesis:
    • Prolactin appears to be the single most important galactopoietic hormone
    • For maintenance of effective and continuous lactation, frequency of suckling (>8/24 hours) is essential

Options A, B & D are incorrect as they do not follow the physiological sequence of breast changes during pregnancy and lactation.

questions.text: Which among the following hormones acts on post ovulatory endometrium?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Progesterone

Explanation:

  • Progesterone is produced by the corpus luteum and plays a key role in preparing the endometrium for potential implantation during the post-ovulatory (luteal) phase of the menstrual cycle.

Hormonal Actions:

  • Promotes endometrial secretory changes
  • Maintains endometrial thickness
  • Essential for early pregnancy maintenance

 

Luteinizing hormone (Option A): LH primarily triggers ovulation through the LH surge and supports corpus luteum formation. It does not directly act on the endometrium. LH's main role is in follicular development and ovulation.

Follicular stimulating hormone (Option B): FSH is responsible for follicular development and estrogen production during the proliferative phase. It has no direct action on post-ovulatory endometrium. Its primary role occurs before ovulation in follicle development.

Oestrogen (Option D): While estrogen is crucial for endometrial proliferation in the first half of the menstrual cycle, it is not the primary hormone acting on post-ovulatory endometrium. Estrogen's main effects occur during the proliferative phase, before ovulation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primipara presents to her obstetrician with complaints of breast pain during breastfeeding. She reports that the pain is associated with difficulty in milk flow. Physical examination reveals engorged breasts with minimal milk expression during attempted feeding. The physician suspects an issue with the milk ejection reflex. Which hormone is responsible for breast pain during breastfeeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Oxytocin

Explanation:

  • The milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex) is primarily mediated by oxytocin, which causes contraction of myoepithelial cells, facilitating milk flow.
  • Difficulty in milk flow and breast pain during breastfeeding are often linked to problems with oxytocin release.

 

Prolactin (Option B): Prolactin is responsible for lactation and milk production, and does not affect milk ejection. Thus, it is not responsible for breast pain during feeding.

Estrogen (Option C): Estrogen increases prolactin production and prolactin receptor expression, but does not directly influence the milk ejection reflex.

Progesterone (Option D): Progesterone induces mammary epithelium maturation but does not affect milk flow.

questions.text: Hormone responsible?
questions.solution:
Breastfeeding is regulated by two key hormones:

  • Prolactin: Stimulates milk production and maintains lactation.
  • Oxytocin: Triggers the milk ejection reflex (let-down reflex) by contracting myoepithelial cells, facilitating milk flow through the ducts.

 

TSH (Option B): Regulates thyroid function, not involved in lactation.

 

GH (Option C): Promotes growth but does not influence breastfeeding.


FSH (Option D): Controls ovarian follicle development, unrelated to lactation.

questions.text: Which sign of pregnancy denotes the following?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Hegar’s sign.

 

Early Signs of Pregnancy

Description

Cause

Week of Pregnancy

Hegar's sign

 

Softening of the lower uterine segment

Increased vascularity and relaxation of the smooth muscle

6-8 weeks of gestation

Chadwick's sign

(Jacquemier’s sign)

Bluish discoloration of the cervix and vagina

 

Increased vascularity in response to hormonal changes in pregnancy.

8th week

Goodell's sign
(Option B)

Softening of the cervix

Increased vascularisation and edema.

6th week

Piskacek's sign

Asymmetric enlargement of the uterus

Lateral implantation of fertilised ovum

-

Palmer's sign

(Option D)

Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions

Due to increased estrogen levels, and the physiological adaptations of the uterus preparing for labor

4-8 weeks

Osiander's sign

(Option C)

Increased pulsations felt through lateral fornices

Increased blood flow uterus by the uterine arteries

8th-12th week

Hartman’s sign/ Placental sign

Implantation bleeding

Attachment of fertilized ovum to the endometrium
